revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox company | name = Public Establishment of the Palace, Museum and National Estate of Versailles | logo = Logo chateau versailles.jpg | caption = | type = [[établissement public à caractère administratif|French public establishment]] | traded_as = | native_name = Établissement public du château, du musée et du domaine national de Versailles | native_name_lang = fr | genre = <!-- Only used with media and publishing companies --> | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | foundation = {{Start date|1995||}} | founder = French Ministry of Culture | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = Versailles | location_country = France | location = [[Palace of Versailles]] | locations = | area_served = | key_people = [[Catherine Pégard]] | industry = | products = | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | aum = <!-- Only used with financial services companies --> | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | homepage = {{URL|www.chateauversailles.fr}} | footnotes = | intl = }} The '''Public Establishment of the Palace, Museum and National Estate of Versailles''' (French: '''Établissement public du château, du musée et du domaine national de Versailles''') is a French [[établissement public à caractère administratif|public establishment]] founded in 1995, and working under the supervision of the [[Minister of Culture (France)|French Ministry of Culture]], in order to administer the [[Palace of Versailles]].
It is headed by [[Catherine Pégard]], president of the public establishment, assisted by Beatrix Saule, as director of the National Museum of Versailles and Trianon.
{{Portal|France}} {{Établissement public à caractère administratif}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Etablissement Public Du Chateau, Du Musee Et Du Domaine National De Versailles}} [[Category:Palace of Versailles]]

revision.comment: Addition of the definition of 'Quality Infrastructure agreed by 11 international and intergovernmental bodies in 2017
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2012}} '''Quality infrastructure''' relates to all fields of [[metrology]], [[standardization]] and [[Test method|testing]], of [[quality management]] and [[conformity assessment]], including [[certification]] and [[accreditation]]. In the past, the abbreviation MSTQ (Metrology, Standardization, Testing and [[Quality Assurance]]) was used for this combination of single elements. Quality infrastructure must ensure: - elaboration and implementation of technical regulations for products and passage from compulsory standards to voluntary ones;
- application of good practice code regarding standardization;
- elimination of all measures that pose [[trade barrier]]s - not only [[customs]] taxes and quantitative restrictions, but all the measures with equivalent (protectionist) effects. [[Category:Quality]] [[Category:Metrology]] [[Category:Standards]] Quality infrastructure: Definition adopted in June 2017 by the DCMAS Network (BIPM, IAF, IEC, ILAC, ISO, ITC, ITU, OIML, UNECE and UNIDO) + the World Bank. “The system comprising the organizations (public and private)together with the policies, relevant legal and regulatory framework, and practices needed to support and enhance the quality, safety and environmental soundness of goods, services and processes. The quality infrastructure is required for the effective operation of domestic markets, and its international recognition is important to enable access to foreign markets. It is a critical element in promoting and sustaining economic development, as well as environmental and social wellbeing. It relies on: • metrology • standardization • accreditation • conformity assessment, and • market surveillance” https://www.bipm.org/utils/common/pdf/QI-definition.pdf

{{Infobox hieroglyphs |name = D21:D46-T12-Y1-R11-D46:X1-B1 |name explanation = Rededjet
''Rededjet'' Westcar-Papyrus, column 9, twenty-second row |}} '''Rededjet''' (also readed as '''Ruddedet''') is the name of a [[fiction|fictitious]] [[ancient Egypt]]ian female [[hero]] appearing in the fifth chapter of a story told in the legendary ''[[Westcar Papyrus]].'' She is said to have fulfilled a [[prophecy]] by giving birth to three future kings during the reign of king ([[pharaoh]]) [[Khufu]] ([[Fourth dynasty of Egypt|4th Dynasty]]), who received the prophecy from a [[magic (paranormal)|magic]]ian named [[Dedi]]. ==Literary person== Rededjet appears only in the fifth story of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' - there is no [[Archeology|archeological]] or [[History|historical]] evidence that she existed. Nevertheless, she is object of great interest for [[historian]]s and [[Egyptologist]]s, since her story gives information about the line of succession at the very beginning of the [[Fifth dynasty of Egypt|fifth dynasty]]. ==The wonder of Rededjet== According to the ''Westcar Papyrus,'' Rededjet has a strong labor, and birth is difficult because she has to expect [[Multiple birth|triplets]]. The [[god]] [[Ra]], Lord of Sachebu, says to the gods [[Isis]], [[Nephthys]], [[Meskhenet]], [[Heqet]] and [[Khnum]]: “May you all go to Rededjet and release her from her trinity of children which are still in her womb and which will exercise their splendid office in the whole realm one day. So they can build [[temple]]s for you, take care of your offering tables, let your drink plates thrive and multiply your god's [[sacrifice]]s.” And so the goddesses turn to Rededjet's house after they had [[Shapeshifting|transformed]] themselves into music-making dancers. The god Khnum himself turns into a porter. When they reach Rededjet's house they meet her husband Ra-User outside at the threshold, wearing his skirt upside-down and whining. The goddesses show him their [[menit]]sA ''Menjt'' is an ancient Egyptian musical instrument; see: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 228. and [[sistrum]]s.A Sistrum is also an ancient Egyptian musical instrument; see: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 228. Thereupon Ra-User says: “See, there is a woman here who is suffering badly, for her birth is problematic.” The goddesses say: “May thou cause that we can see her. See, we know how to relieve.” Ra-User replies: “Feeds!” The gods step in and go immediately to Rededjet, who is lying upstairs. They seal the room and then Isis stands before Rededjet, to catch the babies, Nephthys takes position behind, whilst Heqet accelerates the birth. Now Isis says: “May you, the one who is [[Userkaf|User-Re-ef]], be not too strong in her womb.” And the baby comes out quickly, a healthy child of one cubit in size. His bones are solid, his equipment of limbs being like gold. His headdress is made of real [[lapis lazuli]]. After cutting the umbilical cord, purifying the baby and placing it in a brick-made bed, covered with soft sheets, Khnum makes the body strong. Meskhenet steps by and says: “This is a king who will exercise the rulership over the whole country!” After this, Isis stands again before Rededjet and says: “May you, whose name is [[Sahure]], stop kicking in her womb.” And this baby, too, comes out quickly. It has the same extraordinary appearance like the baby before. And again Meskhenet blesses the child with the words: “This is a king who will exercise the rulership over the whole country!” A third and last time Isis stands before Rededjet and says: “May you, whose name is [[Neferirkare|Keku]],“Keku” is a historical prescription of Neferirkare's birthname “Kakai”; see: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 229. stop being blind in her womb.” And the third baby is blessed by Meskhenet, too. Now the gods leave the room, meet Ra-User and say: “Oh joy! Three children were born to you!” Ra-User replies: “My ladies! What could I do for you? Give this [[barley]] to your porter, may you accept it as a gratuity, for making some [[beer]].” Khnum shoulders himself with the jars of barley and the gods start turning home. On their way, Isis admonishes her companions with the words: “Haven't we come here for a good reason? What would that reason be, if we perform no [[miracle]] to these children! There were nothing we could tell to their father who made us come.″ The gods create three lordly crowns for the children and hide them in the jars of barley. Then they [[conjuration|conjure]] a downpour, as a reason to turn back to Ra-User's house. They say to Ra-User: “Please store the barley in a sealed storeroom for us until we come back from making music in the north.” And the jars with barley are locked in a storeroom. Some weeks later, Rededjet asks her maidservant: “Is our house prepared with all good things?” The maidservant answers: “It is prepared with every good thing, except some jars of beer. They were not brought yet.” Rededjet inquires: “Why is this not so, that the jars with beer were brought?” And the maidservant says: “There is nothing you could produce it with, except the barley of those musicians, the barley that is stored and sealed away.” Rededjet orders: “Go and take some, Ra-User will replace it when he comes home.” And the maidservant opens the storeroom and all of a sudden she hears music, celebrations and cheering from afar - its festive mood typical for a royal [[enthronement|enthroning feast]]. The maid is baffled and tells everything to Rededjet. Rededjet enters the room too and also hears the festive noises. Now nosy she puts her ears on every box and jar, until she finds out, that the noises are coming from the jars of the musicians. Recognising the situation, Rededjet tells everything to Ra-User and they both spend the rest of the day celebrating. One day Rededjet is bickering with the maidservant and the latter one is punished with beating. Infuriated, the maidservant says: “Is it because of that? Is it really because of the three kings you gave birth to? I will go to file charges with the king of [[Lower Egypt|Lower-]] and [[Upper Egypt]], Khufu, justified!” The maidservant leaves the house and goes to her elder brother. He is sitting beside his mother, binding [[flax]] and [[yarn]]. When he sees his sister, he says: “Where do ye go to, lil' sister?” And the maidservant tells him what she is up to. The brother says: “Shall it truly be done to come to me just to make me sup with [[betrayal]]?” He becomes angry and beats her, too. The maidservant now goes away to get some water and a [[Nile crocodile|crocodile]] snatches her. The brother goes to Rededjet to tell her what happened. Rededjet sits on the threshold, crying. The brother says: “What are you crying about, mistress?” Rededjet answers: “It's about this little girl that grew up in this house. Look, she went to go to file charges [...]The text is lost at this spot because of damage to the papyrus; see: Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 51. to the king.” And the brother replies: “See, she came to me to tell [...] that I would go with her, but I beat her and sent her away. When she went off for some water a crocodile snatched her.”Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. In: ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 48 – 52, 103 & 308 – 310.Miriam Lichtheim: ''Ancient Egyptian literature: a book of readings. The Old and Middle Kingdoms'', Band 1. University of California Press 2000, {{ISBN|0-520-02899-6}}, page 215 – 220.Adolf Erman: ''Die Märchen des Papyrus Westcar I. Einleitung und Commentar''. In: ''Mitteilungen aus den Orientalischen Sammlungen''. Heft V, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Berlin 1890. page 12 – 14. ==Modern analysis== Historians and Egyptologists such as [[Adolf Erman]] and [[Kurt Heinrich Sethe]] once thought the tales of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' were mere [[folklore]], despite their knowledge of the historical correctness about the beginning of the fifth dynasty by describing the succession of the kings Userkaf, Sahure and Neferirkare. They also thought the novel of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' to be unfinished.Udo Bartsch: ''Unterhaltungskunst A-Z (Taschenbuch der Künste)''. Henschel, Leipzig 1977 (2. Ausgabe), page 85. Modern Egyptologists such as [[Verena Lepper]] and [[Miriam Lichtheim]] deny this view and they argue that Sethe and Erman may have just failed to see the profundity of the novel. They both evaluate the story as some kind of narrated [[moral]] which deals with the theme of justice and what happens to traitors. Lepper points out, that the story of Rededjet might have been inspired by the historical figure of queen [[Khentkaus I]], who lived and maybe ruled at the end of the [[Fourth dynasty of Egypt|Fourth dynasty]]. Khentkaus I is demonstrably entitled as “mother of two kings” and for a long time it has been thought that she may have borne Userkaf and Sahure. But new evidence shows that at least Sahure had a different mother (Queen [[Neferhetepes (Userkaf)|Neferhetepes]]), the implication of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' that the first three kings of the fifth dynasty had been siblings, is therefore incorrect.Tarek El Awady: ''The royal family of Sahure. New evidence'', in: M. Barta; F. Coppens, J. Krjci (Hrsg.): ''Abusir and Saqqara in the Year 2005'', Prague 2006 {{ISBN|80-7308-116-4}}, p. 192-98 Since in the ''Westcar Papyrus'' Rededjet was concerned with the role of a future king's mother, the parallels between the biographies of the two ladies aroused special attention. The role of the maidservant is evaluated as being a key figure for a modern phrasing of indoctrinations about morality and betrayal. The maidservant wants to betray her mistress and is punished by [[destiny]]. The destiny is depicted here as a crocodile which snatches the traitor. The destination of the whole happening is to ensure the beginning of a new dynasty and by making the only danger disappear, the author of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' artfully creates some kind of [[happy ending]]. Lepper sees a strong clue in the way the story is finalized that the novel of the ''Westcar Papyrus'' actually ends here. The episode in which the crocodile snatches a traitor, is repeated several times, just like a [[refrain]], which is a typical writing element used in ancient Egyptian documents to close a chapter or text.Verena M. Lepper: ''Untersuchungen zu pWestcar. Eine philologische und literaturwissenschaftliche (Neu-)Analyse''. ''Ägyptologische Abhandlungen'', Band 70. Harrassowitz, Wiesbaden 2008, {{ISBN|3-447-05651-7}}, page 121 – 123, 146 – 148 & 298 – 302. ==Archaeological basis== In 2009 archaeological discoveries in Abusir, the royal necropolis of the Fifth Dynasty, have established that Neferirkare was in fact Sahure's son, who was himself Userkaf's son. Egyptologists now believe that the story of Rededjet is based on a conflation of two historical queens named Khentkaus. The first one lived during the 4th Dynasty and may have given birth to two kings, while the second one was the mother of two 5th Dynasty pharaohs, [[Neferefre]] and [[Nyuserre Ini]]. When Nyuserre was on the throne, he revived the cult of the first Khentkaus, as the similarities between both Khentkaus provided him with a genealogical link relating him to his Fourth Dynasty forebears. Th Egyptologist John Nolan believes that the mirroring position and names of the two Khentkaus queens was emphasised so that Nyuserre could legimitise his rule after the troubled times surrounding Neferefre's death. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.cs.st-andrews.ac.uk/~mjn/egyptian/texts/corpus/pdf/Westcar.pdf Transcription and translating of Papyrus Westcar (Berlin Papyrus 3033) into English by the transcription of A. M. Blackman (1988)] (PDF-File) *[http://www.reshafim.org.il/ad/egypt/texts/westcar_papyrus.htm Dedi in Papyrus Westcar at ''reshafim.org''] {{Ancient Egyptian religion footer|collapsed}} [[Category:African folklore]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian literature]] [[Category:Folklore characters]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Superpedia Rumah Ilmu Indonesia | favicon = | logo = | screenshot = [[File:Superpedia screenshot.png|300px|Screenshot of Superpedia]] | caption = | url = http://superpedia.rumahilmu.or.id | commercial = No | type = Wiki | registration = Not required to read, required to contribute | owner = Rumah Ilmu Indonesia Foundation. | language = [[Indonesian language]] | author = | launch date = 19 October 2008 | current status = Active | revenue = }} '''Superpedia''' is an Indonesian free-access online dictionary and encyclopedia initiated by the Rumah Ilmu Indonesia Foundation<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rumahilmu.or.id|title=Rumah Ilmu Indonesia Official Website |publisher=Rumah Ilmu Indonesia}}</ref> on 19 October 2008.
Superpedia runs on the [[MediaWiki]] software, which is also used to run [[Wikimedia Foundation]] projects. At the end of January 2010, the number of articles reached 30,000. At the end of January 2011, it was almost 70,000. Its main page is arranged into educational categories like biology, physics and mathematics, written in the [[Indonesian language]].
==Background== The Superpedia project was created to close the digital literacy gap in Indonesia. The availability of digital dictionaries and encyclopedias is expected to help teachers to improve their knowledge. Only about 20 million of Indonesia's 230 million population can access the internet, so Superpedia is also distributed freely on CD and DVD.
With Indonesian education activists from schools and non-government organizations, Superpedia trains Indonesian educators to use Superpedia<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.klubguru.com/2-view.php?subaction=showfull&id=1243476055&archive=&start_from=&ucat=3& |title=Superpedia socialization at Rembang, Central Java |publisher=Klub Guru Indonesia}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.smkti.net/2010/02/workshop-open-source-untuk-pendidikan.html |title=Superpedia Socialization at Samarinda, East Kalimantan | publisher= SMK TI Samarinda}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.klubguru.com/2-view.php?subaction=showfull&id=1242746462&archive=&start_from=&ucat=7& |title=Superpedia Socialization at Surabaya, East Java |publisher= Klub Guru Indonesia}}</ref> with other [[open-source software]].
==Development scheme== Superpedia is designed to include a variety of Indonesian local content, such as Indonesian local languages, including [[Sundanese language|Sundanese]] and [[Javanese language|Javanese]].
The scheme of the Superpedia development was released in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.rumahilmuindonesia.net/e_learning/skema_superpedia.pdf| title= Superpedia Development Scheme | publisher=Rumah Ilmu Indonesia Foundation}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://groups.yahoo.com/group/cfbe/message/38065 | title= Superpedia Development Scheme | publisher= yahoogroups}}</ref>
==Donation and sponsorship== Because Superpedia is a non-profit project, it depends on donations from users. In early 2010, Intel Indonesia became the first company to support Superpedia.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.inn-world.net/berita_detail1.php?id=2903| title= PT. Intel Indonesia dukung Superpedia (in Indonesian) |publisher= inn-world.net}}</ref>
== Awards == #Bronze Category, Internet Sehat Blog & Content Awards (Indonesian ICT Watch) for week 2, March 2010 <ref name="IICTW">{{cite web|url= http://ictwatch.com/internetsehat/program-unggulan/blog-award-2010/winner-2010/| title= Internet Sehat Blog & Content Award| publisher= detikcom}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = http://ictwatch.com/internetsehat/blog-award-2010/winner-2010/ | title= Indonesian ICT Watch | publisher= ictwatch.com}}</ref> #Silver Category, Internet Sehat Blog & Content Awards (Indonesian ICT Watch) for week 2, April 2010 edition <ref name="IICTW" />
==References== {{Reflist|1}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}}
==External links== *[http://superpedia.rumahilmu.or.id Official website]
[[Category:Online dictionaries]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2008]] [[Category:Indonesian encyclopedias]]

page.title: Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand

revision.comment: replace deprecated template parameters, removed: | slogan = using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=February 2015}} {{More citations needed|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox website | name = ''Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand'' | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | url = {{URL|http://www.teara.govt.nz/}} | company_type = [[Nonprofit]] | location = [[Wellington]], [[New Zealand]] | type = [[Internet encyclopedia project|Online encyclopedia]] | language = English, [[Māori language|Māori]] | registration = | owner = [[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]], [[New Zealand Government]] | author = | launch date = 2005 | commercial = No | alexa = | current status = First build completed 2014 }} '''''Te Ara: The Encyclopedia of New Zealand''''' is an online [[encyclopedia]] created by the [[Ministry for Culture and Heritage]] of the [[Government of New Zealand|New Zealand Government]]. The project was established in 2002 and the website launched in 2005. Its first build was completed in October 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.mch.govt.nz/what-we-do/websites-we-run/te-ara-encyclopedia-new-zealand |title=Te Ara – The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |date=29 January 2016 |work=Ministry for Culture and Heritage |publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage |accessdate=12 November 2016}}</ref>
==History== The encyclopedia was edited by [[historian]] [[Jock Phillips]] and had a staff of writers, editors, image and resource researchers and designers. It is organised by themes, and its first theme focused on telling the stories of New Zealanders. It covers the migration of peoples to New Zealand, and the history of their settlement – both New Zealand's indigenous [[Māori people]], and other immigrant groups.
An overview section, "New Zealand in Brief", presents concise information and facts about the country.
In 2006 a second thematic group of entries was published entitled "Earth, Sea and Sky" and covering ocean fish, sea and shorebirds and other marine life, the interactions of people and the sea, the country's natural resources, and shaping forces such as geology, volcanology, weather and climate. Distinctively New Zealand features are the main focus of the content, and scientific and technical data is presented within its social and human context.
''Te Ara'''s third theme, "The Bush", was launched in late 2007. It covers New Zealand's indigenous landscapes, forests, plants and animals, and the ways that people have used them or attempted to understand them. "The Bush" comprises more than 100 entries, covering such topics as early mapping, [[tramping]], conifer–broadleaf forests, [[taniwha]], Māori exploration, threatened species, logging native forests, [[moa]], [[kiwi]] and a great deal more.
Later themes were The Settled Landscape (2008), Economy and the City (2010), Social Connections (2010), Government and Nation (2012), Daily Life, Sport and Recreation (2013), and Creative and Intellectual Life (2014).<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/who-is-te-ara |title=Who is Te Ara? |work=Te Ara – The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage |accessdate=12 November 2016}}</ref>
The previous official New Zealand encyclopedia was ''[[An Encyclopaedia of New Zealand]]'', first published in 1966 and edited by [[A.H. McLintock]]. A digitised version of this work now forms part of the ''Te Ara'' website. The major New Zealand encyclopedia before that was ''[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]]'', published between 1897 and 1908, a commercial venture in which businesses or people usually paid to be covered.
Entries on topics relating substantially to Māori are presented in [[Māori language|Māori]] as well as English.
The ''[[Dictionary of New Zealand Biography]]'' was integrated into ''Te Ara'' in December 2010.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/te-ara-a-history/page-10 |title=Te Ara – a history – Biographies |work=Te Ara – The Encyclopedia of New Zealand |publisher=Ministry for Culture and Heritage |accessdate=12 November 2016}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of online encyclopedias]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/11/story.cfm?c_id=11&objectid=10496127 My job: Researcher, the ''Encyclopedia of New Zealand'']. ''New Zealand Herald''. Angela McCarthy, 5 March 2008
==External links== *''[http://www.teara.govt.nz Te Ara – The Encyclopedia of New Zealand]'' *[http://blog.teara.govt.nz/ ''Signposts'' – the blog of ''Te Ara''] {{Authority control}}

{{Use British English|date=April 2014}} The '''Testery''' was a section at [[Bletchley Park]], the British [[codebreaking]] station during [[World War II]]. It was set up in July 1942 under Major [[Ralph Tester]].{{sfn|Good|Michie|Timms|1945|loc = 1 Introduction: 14 Organisation, 14A Expansion and Growth, (b) Three periods, p. 28}} Four founder members were Tester himself and three senior cryptographers were Captain [[Jerry Roberts]], Captain Peter Ericsson and Major Denis Oswald. All four were fluent in German. From 1 July 1942 on, this team switched and was tasked with breaking the German High Command’s most top-level code [[Lorenz cipher|Tunny]] after Bill Tutte successfully broke Tunny system in Spring 1942.
The Testery used hand decrypting methods to break Tunny traffic. Within one year of its foundation, the Testery had deciphered 1.5 million texts by these methods. By the war's end in [[Europe]] in May 1945, the Testery had grown to nine cryptographers, a team of 24 ATS, a total staff of 118, organised in three shifts working round the clock.
The logical structure of the Tunny system was worked out by mathematician Bill Tutte ([[William Thomas Tutte]]) in the Spring of 1942. Tunny had 12 wheels, and was more advanced, complex, faster and far more secure than the well-known 3-4 wheeled [[Enigma machine]]. The Germans were convinced that the Tunny cipher system was unbreakable. Tunny was the cipher system which carried only the highest grade of intelligence: messages from the German Army Headquarters in Berlin and the top generals and field marshals on all fronts. Some were signed by Hitler himself. Tens of thousands of Tunny messages were intercepted by the British and broken at Bletchley Park by Captain Roberts and his fellow codebreakers in the Testery. These messages contained much vital insight into top-level German thinking and planning.
After the Testery had been breaking Tunny for a year by hand, the [[Newmanry]] became active from July 1943 under [[Max Newman]]. Mathematicians in the Newmanry used machine methods to speed up breaking Tunny. Early on, a machine called [[Heath Robinson (codebreaking machine)|Heath Robinson]] was produced, to help speed up one stage — breaking of the chi wheels, but the Robinson was slow and not reliable. In February 1944 a new machine called "[[Colossus computer|Colossus]]" became operational; it was the world's first electronic computer. Colossus was designed and built in only ten months by [[Tommy Flowers]] of the G.P.O. (Post Office). This had far greater capacity and speed than the Robinson and so the whole breaking process became much faster. The Colossus was essential for making the very fast counts needed to work out the "de-chis", but the psi-wheels and motor-wheels were still broken by hand in the Testery.
The Testery was hand code-breaking Tunny for 12 months before the Robinson machine was produced and for 19 months before Colossus operated. With the help of the Newmanry, the Testery broke up to 90% of the traffic given to them to work on in the Colossus period.
The information provided by Tunny enabled the Allies to ascertain German movements, saving thousands of lives at critical junctures such as [[D-Day]] and the [[Battle of Kursk]] in the Soviet Union. General [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]] gave the best summary after [[World War II]]. He said that "Bletchley decrypts shortened the War by at least two years". Tunny played a very important role in all of this, a war which was costing at least 10 million lives a year. A great deal of this was down to Bill Tutte.
The story of Enigma (declassified in the 1970s) is well known, but the story of Tunny, Germany's top-secret cipher machine, was only declassified a few years ago. Most of the cryptographers in the Testery died before they could tell their stories. For the first time, on 25 October 2011, a BBC Timewatch programme titled ''Code-breakers: Bletchley Park’s Lost Heroes'', about the Testery, Tunny, Bill Tutte and Tommy Flowers, was produced, featuring testimony from Jerry Roberts.<ref name=timewatch>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b016ltm0 |website=BBC |title= Code-Breakers: Bletchley Park's Lost Heroes |accessdate=4 May 2015}}</ref>
== List of senior executives and codebreakers on [[Lorenz cipher|Tunny]] in the Testery == * [[Ralph Tester]] linguist and head of Testery (not a codebreaker) * [[Jerry Roberts]] shift-leader, linguist and senior codebreaker * Peter Ericsson shift-leader, linguist and senior codebreaker * Victor Masters shift-leader (not a codebreaker) * Denis Oswald linguist and senior codebreaker * [[Peter Hilton]] codebreaker and mathematician * [[Peter Benenson]] codebreaker * Peter Edgerley codebreaker * John Christie codebreaker * Jack Thompson codebreaker * [[Roy Jenkins]] codebreaker (later moved on to wheel setter) * [[Tom Colvill]] General Manager By the war's end in [[Europe]] in May 1945, the Testery had grown to nine cryptographers, a team of 24 ATS, a total staff of 118, organised in three shifts working round the clock.
==See also== *[[Cryptanalysis of the Lorenz cipher]] *[[Cryptanalysis of the Enigma]] *https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GBsfWSQVtYA *http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-20863205
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{Citation | last = Roberts | first = Jerry | author-link = Jerry Roberts | year = 2006 | contribution = Major Tester's Section: The significance of breaking [[Lorenz cipher|Tunny]] | editor-last = Copeland | editor-first = B. Jack | editor-link = Jack Copeland | title = Colossus: The Secrets of Bletchley Park's Codebreaking Computers | publication-place = Oxford | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | pages = 249–259 | isbn = 978-0-19-284055-4 }} * {{Citation | last = Gannon | first = Paul | title = Colossus: Bletchley Park's Greatest Secret | year = 2006 | publisher = Atlantic Books | location = London | isbn = 978-1-84354-331-2 }} * {{Citation | last = Good | first = Jack | author-link = I. J. Good | last2 = Michie | first2 = Donald | author2-link = Donald Michie | last3 = Timms | first3 = Geoffrey | title = General Report on Tunny: With Emphasis on Statistical Methods | year = 1945 | id = UK Public Record Office HW 25/4 and HW 25/5 | url = http://www.alanturing.net/turing_archive/archive/index/tunnyreportindex.html | accessdate = 15 September 2010 }} That version is a facsimile copy, but there is a transcript of much of this document in '.pdf' format at: {{Citation | last = Sale | first = Tony | author-link = Anthony Sale | title = Part of the "General Report on Tunny", the Newmanry History, formatted by Tony Sale| year = 2001 | url = http://www.codesandciphers.org.uk/documents/newman/newman.pdf | accessdate = 20 September 2010 }}, and a web transcript of Part 1 at: {{Citation | last = Ellsbury | first = Graham | title = General Report on Tunny With Emphasis on Statistical Methods | url = http://www.ellsbury.com/tunny/tunny-001.htm | accessdate = 3 November 2010 }} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}

{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2015}} {{one source|date=October 2009}} <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: [[Image:TheRocklopediaFakebandica.jpg|thumb|Cover of ''The Rocklopedia Fakebandica'' (2004, Thomas Dunne Books, St. Martin's Press)]] --> '''''The Rocklopedia Fakebandica''''', by T. Mike Childs, is an illustrated encyclopedia of [[fictional musical group]]s and musicians, as seen in movies and television. It was officially released November 6, 2004. The book catalogs such better-known fake bands as [[Spinal Tap (band)|Spinal Tap]], [[The Blues Brothers]], [[The Rutles]], and [[The Chipmunks]], along with dozens of less well known ones. The book takes a light-hearted, humorous approach, often pointing out the discrepancies between the experiences of real bands and musicians and the unlikely adventures fictional ones have.
The book grew out of a website started by the author in 2000. The website includes fictional bands from other sources, such as books and TV commercials, as well as many bands not found in the book.
==See also== *[[List of fictional music groups]]
==External links== *[http://www.fakebands.com Official site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rocklopedia Fakebandica, The}} [[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:Online encyclopedias]] [[Category:Popular culture books]] [[Category:Encyclopedias of music]]

revision.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Time Out magazine | logo = | image_file = File:Time Out London Magazine free publication launch cover.jpg | image_size = | image_caption = | editor = Caroline McGinn | editor_title = Editor-in-chief, London | editor2 = Gail Tolley | editor_title2 = Editor London | editor3 = Jillian Anthony | editor_title3 = Editor, New York | editor4 = | format = Culture, entertainment and events guide | frequency = Weekly, monthly and quarterly | circulation = 6.5 million | founder = Tony Elliott | founded = {{start date and age|1968}} | company = [[Time Out Group|Time Out Group Ltd.]] | country = United Kingdom | based = London, England | language = English, multilingual | website = {{url|http://www.timeout.com/}} }} '''''Time Out''''' is a British [[travel]] magazine published by [[Time Out Group]].{{cite web| url=http://www.growthbusiness.co.uk/news-and-market-deals/mergers-and-acquisitions/1301613/oakley-capital-buys-stake-in-time-out.thtml| title=Oakley Capital buys stake in Time Out| date=25 November 2010| publisher=Growth Business| accessdate=15 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924024013/http://www.growthbusiness.co.uk/news-and-market-deals/mergers-and-acquisitions/1301613/oakley-capital-buys-stake-in-time-out.thtml| archivedate=24 September 2015| df=dmy-all}} ''Time Out'' started its publication in 1968 and has expanded its editorial recommendations to 108 cities worldwide.{{cite web| url=http://gorkana.com/news/consumer/little-black-book/gorkana-meetstime-out-london/| archive-url=https://archive.is/20150414081350/http://gorkana.com/news/consumer/little-black-book/gorkana-meetstime-out-london/| dead-url=yes| archive-date=14 April 2015| title=Gorkana meets...Time Out London | date= 26 January 2015 |publisher=Gorkana| accessdate=15 June 2015}} In 2012, the magazine became a free publication with a weekly readership of over 307,000. ''Time Out''{{'}}s global market presence includes partnerships with [[Nokia]] and [[mobile apps]] for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] operating systems.{{cite web| url=https://www.pehub.com/2011/12/time-out-acquires-kelkoo-select/| title=Time Out acquires Kelkoo Select| date=12 December 2011| publisher=PE Hub| accessdate=15 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150710060100/https://www.pehub.com/2011/12/time-out-acquires-kelkoo-select/| archivedate=10 July 2015| df=dmy-all}} It was the recipient of the International Consumer Magazine of the Year award in both 2010 and 2011 and the renamed International Consumer Media Brand of the Year in 2013 and 2014.{{cite web| url=http://sports.tmcnet.com//news/2012/01/23/6070746.htm| title=Time Out acquires Whatsonstage.com| date=23 January 2012| publisher=Sports Techy| accessdate=15 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304110617/http://sports.tmcnet.com//news/2012/01/23/6070746.htm| archivedate=4 March 2016| df=dmy-all}}{{cite web| url=http://www.timeout.com/about/time-out-group/latest-news/worldwide-brand-of-the-year-again| title=Worldwide brand of the year... again!| date=15 July 2014| publisher=Time Out| accessdate=15 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609043407/http://www.timeout.com/about/time-out-group/latest-news/worldwide-brand-of-the-year-again| archivedate=9 June 2015| df=dmy-all}} ==History== [[File:Time Out Hong Kong Magazine Launch Cover.jpg|thumb|''Time Out Hong Kong'' launch cover]] ''Time Out'' was first published in 1968 as a London listings magazine by [[Tony Elliott (publisher)|Tony Elliott]], who used birthday money to produce a one-sheet pamphlet.{{cite news | url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/419e3992-0665-11e2-bd29-00144feabdc0.html | title=Time Out abandons its cover price| author = Robert Budden| date= 24 September 2012| newspaper= Financial Times| accessdate=16 June 2015}}, with [[Bob Harris (radio)|Bob Harris]] as co-editor.Old Grey Whistle Test DVD Vol 3; Bob Harris speaking before Track 3 The first product was titled "Where It's At", before being inspired by [[Dave Brubeck]]'s album ''[[Time Out (album)|Time Out]]''.{{cite web| url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/57/Time-Out-Group-Ltd.html| title=Time Out Group Ltd.| publisher=Reference for business| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618151622/http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/57/Time-Out-Group-Ltd.html| archivedate=18 June 2015| df=dmy-all}} Time Out began as an alternative magazine alongside other members of the [[underground press]] in the UK, but by 1980 it had abandoned its original collective decision-making structure and its commitment to equal pay for all its workers, leading to a strike and the foundation of a competing magazine, ''[[City Limits (magazine)|City Limits]]'', by former staffers. By now its former radicalism has all but vanished.Phillips, A. (2007). "The Alternative Press". In K. Coyer, T. Dowmunt & A. Fountain (eds.), ''The Alternative Media Handbook'' (p. 54). London; New York: Routledge. As one example of its early editorial stance, in 1976 London's ''Time Out'' published the names of 60 purported CIA agents stationed in England.{{cite book |title= How We Got Here: The '70s|last= Frum|first= David|authorlink= David Frum |year= 2000|publisher= Basic Books|location= New York |isbn= 0-465-04195-7|page= 51}} Early issues had a print run of around 5,000 and would evolve to a weekly circulation of 110,000 as it shed its radical roots.{{cite web| url= http://www.adweek.com/news/press/can-time-out-s-tony-elliott-weather-storm-132910?page=1| title= Can Time Out's Tony Elliott weather the storm? The founder of iconic magazines cedes control to keep his dream alive| author= Lucia Moses| date= 27 June 2011| publisher= Adweek| accessdate= 16 June 2015| deadurl= no| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150618152830/http://www.adweek.com/news/press/can-time-out-s-tony-elliott-weather-storm-132910?page=1| archivedate= 18 June 2015| df= dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/item/58896/259/263/3|author= Reynolds, John|title=Moving Beyond its City Limits|publisher=''Marketing Week''|date= 6 December 2007}} The flavour of the magazine was almost wholly the responsibility of its designer, Pearce Marchbank. Marchbank was invited by Tony Elliott to join the embryonic Time Out in 1971. Turning it into a weekly, he produced its classic logo, [and] established its strong identity and its editorial structure—all still used world-wide to this day. He also conceived and designed the first of the Time Out guide books. ... He continued to design for Time Out for many years. Each week, his powerful, witty Time Out covers became an essential part of London life.{{cite web|url=http://www.pearcemarchbank.com/pearcemarchbankb.html|title=Pearce Marchbank - Biography|author=|date=|website=www.pearcemarchbank.com|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161027062056/http://pearcemarchbank.com/pearcemarchbankb.html|archivedate=27 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} Elliott launched ''Time Out New York'' (''TONY''), his North American magazine debut, in 1995. The magazine procured young and upcoming talent to provide cultural reviews for young New Yorkers at the time. The success of ''TONY'' led to the introduction of ''Time Out New York Kids'', a quarterly magazine aimed at families. The expansion continued with Elliott licensing the Time Out brand worldwide spreading the magazine to 39 cities including Istanbul, Dubai, Beijing, Hong Kong and Lisbon. Additional Time Out products included travel magazines, city guides, and books. In 2010, Time Out became the official publisher of travel guides and tourist books for the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games.{{cite web| url=http://www.thebookseller.com/news/carlton-wiley-and-time-out-official-publishers-london-olympics| title=Carlton, Wiley and Time Out official publishers for London Olympics| author=Catherine Neilan| date=17 March 2010| publisher=The Bookseller| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304085417/http://www.thebookseller.com/news/carlton-wiley-and-time-out-official-publishers-london-olympics| archivedate=4 March 2016| df=dmy-all}} ''Time Out''{{’}}s need to expand to digital platforms led to Elliott, sole owner of the group until November 2010, to sell half of ''Time Out'' London and 66 percent of ''TONY'' to private equity group Oakley Capital, valuing the company at £20million.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11844925|title=Time Out publisher sells 50% stake|publisher=BBC News|date=26 November 2010|accessdate=26 November 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101127044834/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11844925|archivedate=27 November 2010|df=dmy-all}} The group, founded by [[Peter Dubens]], was owned by Tony Elliott and Oakley Capital until 2016, the agreement provided capital for investment to expand the brand. ''Time Out'' has subsequently launched websites for an additional 33 cities including Delhi, Washington D.C., Boston, Manchester and Bristol.when it was listed on London's AIM stock exchange. In June 2016, Time Out Group underwent an IPO and is listed on London's AIM stock exchange.{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-timeout-ipo-idUKKCN0YV1MF|title=Time Out to Raise £90 Million in London Listing|publisher=Reuters|first=Noor Zanib|last=Hussain|date=9 June 2016|access-date=22 September 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160923111529/http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-timeout-ipo-idUKKCN0YV1MF|archivedate=23 September 2016|df=dmy-all}} ==City editions== ===''Time Out London''=== [[File:Time Out London Magazine1.jpg|thumb|''Time Out London'' first issue]] The London edition of ''Time Out'' became a free magazine in September 2012.{{cite web| url= http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/1213088/| title= Time Out makes capital gains as free magazine| date= 26 September 2013| publisher= Campaign| accessdate= 16 June 2015| deadurl= no| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150710120546/http://www.campaignlive.co.uk/news/1213088/| archivedate= 10 July 2015| df= dmy-all}} ''Time Out''{{'}}s London magazine was hand distributed at central London stations, and received its first official ABC Certificate for October 2012 showing distribution of over 305,000 copies per week which was the largest distribution in the history of the brand.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/aug/02/time-out-free-london-edition| title=Time Out goes free, London edition of listings magazine to drop cover price| author=Mark Sweney| date=1 August 2012| newspaper=The Guardian| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626130509/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2012/aug/02/time-out-free-london-edition| archivedate=26 June 2015| df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/1161516/Free-Time-hits-three-month-circulation-target-first-month|title=Free Time Out hits three-month circulation target in first month|work=mediaweek.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121203033636/http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/news/1161516/Free-Time-hits-three-month-circulation-target-first-month/|archivedate=3 December 2012|df=dmy-all}} This strategy increased revenue by 80 percent with continued upsurge.{{cite news| url=http://www.foliomag.com/2015/54876/| title=Time Out New York Transforms Into A (Mostly) Free Weekly| author=Caysey Welton| date=2 April 2015| work=[[Folio (magazine)|Folio]]| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609052353/http://www.foliomag.com/2015/54876/| archivedate=9 June 2015| df=dmy-all}} ''Time Out'' has also invited a number of guest columnists to write for the magazine. The columnist as of 2014 was [[Giles Coren]].{{cite news| url=http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1320240/time-hires-giles-coren-columnist| title=Time Out hires Giles Coren as columnist| author=Arif Durrani| date=11 March 2014| work=[[Haymarket Media Group|Media Week]]| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150712231234/http://www.mediaweek.co.uk/article/1320240/time-hires-giles-coren-columnist| archivedate=12 July 2015| df=dmy-all}} ===''Time Out New York''=== In April 2015, ''Time Out'' switched its New York magazine to the free distribution model to increase the reader base and grow brand awareness. This transition doubled circulation by increasing its Web audience, estimated around 3.5 million unique visitors a month.{{cite news| url=https://nypost.com/2015/04/01/time-out-new-york-switching-to-all-free-distribution-model| title=Time Out New York switching to all-free distribution model| author=Keith J. Kelly| date=1 April 2015| newspaper=New York Post| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626201453/http://nypost.com/2015/04/01/time-out-new-york-switching-to-all-free-distribution-model/| archivedate=26 June 2015| df=dmy-all}} ''Time Out'' increased its weekly magazine circulation to over 305,000 copies complementing millions of digital users of ''Time Out'' New York. Free magazines are distributed at bars, restaurants, gyms, subway stations, and theaters and the web content separate from the magazine is free. In addition, a subscription service is offered to those that prefer the magazine to be physically delivered and paid subscribers have access to a digital edition of the magazine. ===''Time Out New York Kids''=== In 1996, following the launch of ''TONY'' magazine, ''Time Out New York Kids'' was launched as a paid-for quarterly title available via subscription and news stand with a circulation of 55,000.{{cite web| url=http://www.timeout.com/about/commercial-opportunities/north-america/new-york-city/time-out-new-york-kids| title=Time Out New York Kids| publisher=Time Out| accessdate=16 June 2015| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150617101708/http://www.timeout.com/about/commercial-opportunities/north-america/new-york-city/time-out-new-york-kids| archivedate=17 June 2015| df=dmy-all}} ===''Time Out Tel Aviv''=== ''Time Out Tel Aviv'' (in Hebrew) is sold once a week, covering the [[Tel Aviv]], Israel, area.{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.co.il|title=טיים אאוט ישראל – קל להיכנס, קל לצאת|author=|date=|website=טיים אאוט|accessdate=2 May 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180322133233/https://timeout.co.il/|archivedate=22 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} ==Additional ventures== In addition to magazines and travel books and websites, Time Out started opening branded [[food hall]]s in 2014, starting with the [[Time Out Market Lisboa]] in Lisbon, Portugal.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/10/12/time-out-market-to-open-in-shoreditch-in-2017/|title=Time Out Market to open in Shoreditch in 2017|first=Jillian|last=Ambrose|date=12 October 2016|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2018|via=www.telegraph.co.uk|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213141141/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2016/10/12/time-out-market-to-open-in-shoreditch-in-2017/|archivedate=13 February 2018|df=dmy-all}} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.timeout.com/ ''Time Out'' Global Homepage] * [https://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/dec/08/time-out-to-cut-about-40-staff-in-uk-and-us"Time Out to cut about 40 staff in UK and US"] * [http://www.timeoutdubai.com/ ''Time Out'' Time Out Dubai] * [http://www.timeoutabudhabi.com/ ''Time Out'' Time Out Abu Dhabi] * [http://www.timeoutbahrain.com/''Time Out'' Time Out Bahrain] * [http://www.timeoutdoha.com/ ''Time Out'' Time Out Doha] {{DEFAULTSORT:Time Out Group}} [[Category:1968 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British lifestyle magazines]] [[Category:British monthly magazines]] [[Category:British quarterly magazines]] [[Category:British weekly magazines]] [[Category:Cultural magazines]] [[Category:Entertainment magazines]] [[Category:London magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1968]] revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = Total Resistance | title_orig = Der totale Widerstand: Eine Kleinkriegsanleitung für Jedermann | translator = | image = Cover of Der totale Widerstand (3rd ed. 1966).jpg.png | caption = Cover of the 3rd German language edition (1966) | author = [[Hans von Dach]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = Switzerland | language = German | series = | subject = Military | genre = Instruction manual | publisher = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | media_type = | pages = | isbn = 3-9521096-1-4 | isbn_note=
{{ISBN|978-0-87364-021-3}}
{{ISBN|978-1607963042}} (English edition) | oclc= 75856605 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Total Resistance''''', originally published in German as ''Der totale Widerstand: Eine Kleinkriegsanleitung für Jedermann'' ("Total Resistance: A Guerrilla Warfare Manual for Everyone") is a [[guerilla warfare]] manual. It was written in 1957 by the Swiss army officer [[Hans von Dach]] to prepare the Swiss population for an occupation of Switzerland by [[Warsaw Pact]] forces, an eventuality then considered possible in the context of the [[Cold War]]. The book has been republished as pirated translations in dozens of languages in numerous countries abroad, and notably found use by left-wing terror groups in the 1960s and 70s.{{cite news|page=12|last=Tribelhorn|first=Marc|title=Terror-Rezepte aus der Schweiz: Über die erstaunliche "Karriere" eines Guerilla-Handbuchs, das einiges über die Eidgenossenschaft im Kalten Krieg erzählt|url=http://www.nzz.ch/aktuell/schweiz/terror-rezepte-fuer-guerilleros-1.18123000|accessdate=26 July 2013|newspaper=[[Neue Zürcher Zeitung]]|date=26 July 2013}} ==Publication== ''Der totale Widerstand'' was first published in 1957 in seven volumes by the Swiss Non-Commissioned Officers' Association (''Schweizer Unteroffiziersverband'', SUOV) with an intent of broad dissemination to the Swiss population. The book was a commercial success, being reprinted five times and selling in the tens of thousands, notably in West Germany and Austria. It became by far the most well-known of von Dach's more than a hundred works on military tactics.{{cite journal|last=Mantovani|first=Mauro|title=Der "Volksaufstand": Vorstellungen und Vorbereitungen der Schweiz im 19. und 20. Jh.|journal=MILITARY POWER REVUE der Schweizer Armee|url=http://www.vtg.admin.ch/internet/vtg/de/home/schweizerarmee/organisation/hkaneu/milak.parsys.00015.downloadList.22576.DownloadFile.tmp/22.5.2012volksaufstandm.mantovanipdf.pdf|year=2012|volume=1|pages=52–60|accessdate=26 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324001141/http://www.vtg.admin.ch/internet/vtg/de/home/schweizerarmee/organisation/hkaneu/milak.parsys.00015.downloadList.22576.DownloadFile.tmp/22.5.2012volksaufstandm.mantovanipdf.pdf|archivedate=24 March 2014|df=}} ==Contents== The book is a manual for [[irregular warfare]] against an occupying force, intended to be used by civilians rather than by soldiers. It presumes a form of irregular resistance involving no arms heavier than light infantry arms: rifles, hand grenades and mines. The topics covered in the first volume include: *the operative, tactical, technical and psychological basics of guerrilla warfare, such as sabotage, assassination and conduct under torture, *the establishment, organization and command of guerrilla warfare units and civilian resistance movements, *enemy methods of suppressing and combating guerrilla warfare. The other volumes describe the manufacture and use of basic weapons: chemical weapons (vol. 2), the ''Partisan'' 9mm submachine gun (vol. 3), the ''TARN'' pistol (vol. 4), [[improvised explosive devices]] (vol. 5), the ''TELL'' noise suppressor (vol. 6) and hand grenades (vol. 7). ==Reception== ===In Switzerland=== While popular in the militia officer corps, the book was not well received by senior Army leaders, who favored a defence policy based on conventional combined-arms and mechanized warfare rather than irregular warfare. In 1974, the Chief of the General Staff vetoed the publication of ''Total Resistance'' as an army manual, partly because of concerns that it advocated conduct that violated the [[laws of war]]. When the Swiss Army did establish a secret [[stay-behind]] organization, [[Projekt-26|P-26]], in the 1970s, it was conceived as a top-down, cadre-led structure rather than the broad, decentralized civilian resistance movement envisioned by von Dach. Nonetheless, the book remains part of the curriculum of the Swiss Army Military Academy at the [[ETH Zurich]] as one of the "classics of the history of strategy and the theory of war."{{cite web|last=Mantovani|first=Mauro|title=Klassiker der Strategiegeschichte und der Kriegstheorie: Quellensammlung|url=http://www.vtg.admin.ch/internet/vtg/de/home/schweizerarmee/organisation/hkaneu/milak/militaerwissenschaftliche/strategische_studien/vorlesungsunterlagen.parsys.40643.DownloadFile.tmp/quellenstratstud2012.pdf|publisher=Militärakademie an der ETH Zürich / Dozentur Strategische Studien|accessdate=26 July 2013|date=January 2012}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} ===Abroad=== The book soon found unexpected success abroad. In 1965, U.S. special forces published an unauthorized translation entitled ''Total Resistance – Swiss Army Guide to Guerilla Warfare and Underground Operations''. Other pirated translations continued to be published in dozens of languages in countries ranging from Angola to Vietnam. In the Soviet Union, the book was derided as "nonsense" in a 1984 newspaper article. ''Total Resistance'' became notably popular as an instruction manual for several left-wing terror groups active in the 1960s and 70s. According to Swiss and European police reports of the time, it was widely disseminated in left-wing extremist circles, and its tactics were used in bomb attacks in Southern Tyrol, New York and Frankfurt, as well as in unrests in Paris. In Germany, the book was often found in police searches, including with [[Red Army Faction]] members. Since 1988, ''Der totale Widerstand'' has been the only Swiss book whose distribution is restricted in Germany because it is indexed by the [[Federal Department for Media Harmful to Young Persons]] as "conducive to confusing the social ethics of children and young people, and to promote their inclination to violence". ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Military books]] [[Category:Guerrilla warfare handbooks and manuals]]

revision.comment: /* Artefacts */clean up; HTTP→HTTPS for [[British Museum]], replaced: http://www.britishmuseum.org/ → https://www.britishmuseum.org/ using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{coord|51|58|11|N|5|4|25|W|region:GB|display=title}} {{Infobox Artefact | name = Tregwynt Hoard | image =[[File:Tregwynt Mansion Hoard 305621 c70e8ac9.jpg|300px|alt=The large house where the hoard was found]] | image_caption =The mansion where the hoard was found. | material = [[Gold]], [[silver]], pottery and lead. | created = est. 1648 | period = [[English Civil War]] | discovered = Tregwynt Mansion, Nr Fishguard, in 1996 | location = }} The '''Tregwynt Hoard''' is a mid-17th century [[hoard]] of coins found at [[Tregwynt Mansion]] near [[Fishguard]] in [[Pembrokeshire]], [[Wales]], in 1996. The hoard is now in [[National Museum Wales]]. The treasure consisted of 33 gold coins, 467 silver coins and a gold ring.<ref name=bm2/> This was the first [[English Civil War]] hoard found in Pembrokeshire.<ref name=mow/>
==Local history== This mansion had been the scene where the invasion of the French was first reported to Colonel Thomas Knox who was at a dance there on 23 February 1797. Knox, who had been appointed by his father William Knox went into a strategic withdrawal to [[Haverfordwest]] which is in land. The retreat of the ''Fishguard Fencibles'' was halted by Lord Cawdor who persuaded Knox to advance. The ''Fencibles'' who were local volunteers saw off the force of 1200 French convicts. It was reported the local population assisted in seeing off the "last invasion of British soil". The [[BBC]] reported that there was a local story that the guests at the dance hid their valuables and that when a hoard was discovered it was thought initially to have confirmed the tale.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/south_west/6949422.stm Civil War coin hoard 'goes home'], BBC, 17 August 2007, accessed July 2010</ref>
==The hoard== The hoard can be dated from the date of the last coin that was included in the hoard and this came from 1647 or 1648. This date is at the end of English Civil War and these troubles are the probable reason for the hoard being deposited. There are over 200 hoards that date from the time of the civil war. This was the first civil war hoard found in Pembrokeshire.<ref name=mow/> These goods were hidden by an outbuilding of the Tregwynt Mansion. They were discovered in 1996 as a result of building work resulting from the construction of a tennis court. Because a few coins had been found, the ground was searched by a metal detector and Roy Lewis discovered many more coins. By the end, a [[J. C. Bamford|JCB digger]] was involved and in addition to the coins they also found lead sheeting which is thought to have covered the hoard and a ring with a motto inside it. The inscription reads ''"Better death than false of faith"'' (spelling updated).<ref name=mow>[http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/en/rhagor/article/1908/ Tregwynt Hoard], Museum of Wales, retrieved July 2010</ref>
The hoard was probably hidden at the time that [[Oliver Cromwell]] came to Pembrokeshire to settle the local Royalists who were in rebellion. The value at the time was over 50 pounds and this would have been over four years wages for an average soldier. The money may have been saved by Llewellin Harries who lived at the mansion at the time with his twelve children.<ref name=bm2/>
==Artefacts== The treasure consisted of 33 gold coins, 467 silver coins and a gold [[Posie ring]].<ref name=bm2>{{Cite web | title=The Tregwynt Hoard | publisher=[[British Museum]] | url=https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/loan_in/t/the_tregwynt_hoard.aspx | accessdate=2010-07-14 }}</ref> Amongst the coins were: *The latest coin is a 1647 or 1648 shilling bearing a sceptre *A Scottish 1602 coin of [[James VI of Scotland]] *A [[Charles I of England]] one pound gold coin *A Charles I silver half-crown struck at an emergency mint in Shrewsbury in 1642<ref name=mow/>
==See also== * [[List of hoards in Britain]]
== Notes == {{reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Doctrine of Air Supremacy */clean up; http→https for [[Google Books]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
'''Trenchardism''' describes the domestic and foreign policies associated in Britain with Air Marshal [[Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard|Hugh Trenchard]] in successive roles as [[Chief of the Air Staff (United Kingdom)|Chief of the Air Staff]] from 1919–30 and [[Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis|Head of the Metropolitan Police]] from 1931–35.
==Doctrine of Air Supremacy==
Trenchard was a keen advocate of British airpower. A key figure in the development of the [[Royal Air Force]], Trenchard advocated the use of aircraft to destroy an enemy's war making capacity, a view influential in developing Britain's [[Strategic bombing during World War II|strategic bombing of Germany]] during the [[Second World War]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Smart|first=Nick|title=British Strategy and Politics During the Phony War: Before the Balloon Went Up|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2alsusMfcK8C&pg=PA34&lpg=PA34&dq=trenchardism&source=bl&ots=oO1Ir4XYhF&sig=mNijzP6rhV9QjzYyvHFWxz2lQGI&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MiJeUMSJPInS0QXR9YH4Bg&ved=0CCEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=trenchardism&f=false|work=Google Books|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
Trenchard also advocated a system of 'air control' to maintain order in [[British Empire|Britain's colonial empire]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Deer|first=Patrick|title=Culture in Camouflage: War, Empire and Modern British Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ujOyRFt-wTwC&pg=PA64&lpg=PA64&dq=trenchardism&source=bl&ots=wDJLrs1Ywk&sig=LMoWZScrBhzbTbG97yL6VWHk7HM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=MiJeUMSJPInS0QXR9YH4Bg&ved=0CDAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=trenchardism&f=false|work=Google Books|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
==Trenchardism in domestic policy==
Campaigners on the Left in Britain resented what they deemed Trenchard's militarisation of policing in London and saw innovations such as the [[Hendon Police College|Metropolitan Police College]] not as the professionalisation Trenchard claimed but a deliberate assault on Britain's traditional style of consensus policing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Answer the Fascist challenge|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/education/topics/hyde-park.htm|work=MEPO 2/3074|publisher=The National Archives|accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
This view of Trenchardism as an authoritarian doctrine was exacerbated by specific police tactics used against hunger marchers in London, including use of batons.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hunger March speeches|url=http://www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/education/topics/marchers.htm|work=HO 144/18186|publisher=The National Archives|accessdate=11 October 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Hugh Trenchard as Metropolitan Police Commissioner]]
{{Trenchard}}
